resources.string: You should eat more nutritious foods
Your nutritional status index is ideal and should be maintained
You need to have a reasonable diet to not fall into obesity
Your condition starts to get worse if you don\'t lose weight, you should eat sensibly and exercise regularly
Your condition is really serious, you can suffer from obesity diseases, you should consult with your doctor to have a reasonable diet.
Your condition is especially serious, and the diseases related to obesity can kill you, you should see your doctor to have a reasonable diet and exercise regularly

string-array.name: activity_levels_for_the_day
string-array.item: Mild exercise – exercise 1–3 times a week
Moderate exercise – exercise 3–5 times a week
Very active – exercise 5–6 times a week
Heavy exercise – exercise or do hard work

resources.string: If you have any questions, contact us with:
280 An Duong Vuong,Ward 4, District 5, HCM city
- The one-repetition maximum test (1RM) is one of the most common measures used to find out the heaviest weight you can press just once (but not twice). You can also do multiple-repetition tests.
- Your BMR is your ‘basal metabolic rate’. It’s the amount of energy your body burns if you did nothing but rest for 24 hours.
- It represents the minimum amount of energy, i.e. calories, your body requires to remain functioning.
- It doesn’t include the calories your body uses for exercise or general movement
- Body mass index (BMI) is a measure of body fat based on height and weight that applies to adult men and women.

- Your TDEE is your ‘total daily energy expenditure’. This is the amount of energy, i.e. calories, your body burns every day performing its bodily functions and also physical movement like daily activities and exercise.
- It’s useful to calculate your TDEE to know how many calories you should be eating to maintain, lose, or gain weight (dependent on your goals).
- Not everyone’s TDEE is the same, as lots of factors can affect how much energy your body burns every day, like age, gender, height, weight, genetics, and activity level (i.e. how much you move).
